<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 118, 380, 146]]<|/det|>
# Cambridge IGCSEâ„¢

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 171, 184, 189]]<|/det|>
PHYSICS Paper 1 Multiple Choice (Core)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[891, 171, 905, 186]]<|/det|>
0625/11

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[783, 193, 907, 209]]<|/det|>
May/June 2025 45 minutes

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 248, 507, 266]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the multiple choice answer sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[98, 279, 438, 296]]<|/det|>
You will need: Multiple choice answer sheet Soft clean eraser

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[217, 306, 540, 323]]<|/det|>
Soft pencil (type B or HB is recommended)

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 336, 231, 353]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 351, 603, 379]]<|/det|>
- There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. - For each question there are four possible answers \(\mathbf{A}, \mathbf{B}, \mathbf{C}\) and \(\mathbf{D}\). Choose the one you consider correct

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 382, 682, 399]]<|/det|>
and record your choice in soft pencil on the multiple choice answer sheet. - Follow the instructions on the multiple choice answer sheet.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 413, 277, 430]]<|/det|>
- Write in soft pencil. - Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the multiple choice answer sheet in the

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 442, 521, 459]]<|/det|>
spaces provided unless this has been done for you. - Do not use correction fluid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[128, 472, 366, 489]]<|/det|>
- Do not write on any bar codes. - You may use a calculator.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 503, 680, 522]]<|/det|>
- Take the weight of 1.0 kg to be 9.8 N (acceleration of free fall \(=9.8 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}^{2}\) ).

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 546, 222, 563]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION - The total mark for this paper is 40 .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[97, 579, 443, 594]]<|/det|>
- Each correct answer will score one mark. - Any rough working should be done on this question paper.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 601, 91]]<|/det|> 1 The diagram shows a measuring cylinder containing liquid. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[391, 105, 603, 333]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 347, 567, 362]]<|/det|> What is the volume of liquid in the measuring cylinder? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 372, 228, 389]]<|/det|> A \(\quad 13.0 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 372, 395, 389]]<|/det|> B \(\quad 13.5 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 372, 562, 389]]<|/det|> C \(\quad 16.0 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 372, 727, 389]]<|/det|> D \(\quad 17.0 \mathrm{~cm}^{3}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 419, 689, 435]]<|/det|> 2 Which statement about the speed and velocity of an object is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 449, 690, 465]]<|/det|> A The speed and velocity of an object are always greater than zero. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 474, 623, 490]]<|/det|> B The speed of an object is always greater than its velocity. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 499, 688, 516]]<|/det|> C The velocity of an object is equal to its speed in a given direction. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 525, 777, 542]]<|/det|> D Speed can be measured in m/s but velocity can only be measured in \(\mathrm{km} / \mathrm{h}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 570, 521, 585]]<|/det|> 3 The table shows a student's times in three races. <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[341, 597, 658, 701]]<|/det|>
race
distance / m
time / s
1
100
12
2
150
17
3
200
25
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 714, 835, 731]]<|/det|> What is the order of the student's average speeds in each race, from lowest to highest? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 745, 245, 758]]<|/det|> A \(1 \rightarrow 2 \rightarrow 3\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 745, 413, 758]]<|/det|> B \(1 \rightarrow 3 \rightarrow 2\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 745, 579, 758]]<|/det|> C \(2 \rightarrow 1 \rightarrow 3\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 745, 745, 758]]<|/det|> D \(3 \rightarrow 1 \rightarrow 2\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 326, 283, 357]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 367, 153, 384]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 393, 153, 410]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 419, 153, 436]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 490, 896, 508]]<|/det|> 6 A car is driven from rest on a long straight road. The car engine exerts a constant driving force. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 521, 918, 538]]<|/det|> The diagram shows the horizontal forces acting on the car. The resistive forces are proportional to the speed of the car. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[272, 564, 738, 661]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 679, 570, 694]]<|/det|> Why does the car eventually reach a maximum speed? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 706, 766, 722]]<|/det|> A The resistive forces decrease to make the acceleration of the car negative. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 731, 731, 748]]<|/det|> B The resistive forces decrease to make the acceleration of the car zero. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 757, 760, 774]]<|/det|> C The resistive forces increase to make the acceleration of the car negative. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 782, 725, 799]]<|/det|> D The resistive forces increase to make the acceleration of the car zero.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 648, 91]]<|/det|> 7 A mattress placed on a bed contains many compression springs. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[333, 103, 666, 213]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 224, 758, 241]]<|/det|> Which energy store of the mattress increases when a person lies on the bed? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 254, 333, 270]]<|/det|> A gravitational potential <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 279, 231, 294]]<|/det|> B chemical <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 304, 211, 321]]<|/det|> C elastic <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 330, 211, 347]]<|/det|> D kinetic <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 374, 686, 393]]<|/det|> 8 Which energy resource does not contain a store of chemical energy? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 404, 211, 419]]<|/det|> A biofuel <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 429, 189, 446]]<|/det|> B coal <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 454, 256, 471]]<|/det|> C nuclear fuel <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 480, 177, 497]]<|/det|> D oil <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 525, 896, 543]]<|/det|> 9 A person carries 20 tiles from the ground to the roof of a house. Each tile has a mass of 1.2 kg . The roof of the house is 15 m above the ground. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 570, 869, 587]]<|/det|> How much work does the person do against gravity on the tiles in carrying them to the roof? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 599, 189, 614]]<|/det|> A 37 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[281, 599, 366, 614]]<|/det|> B 180 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 599, 535, 614]]<|/det|> C 360 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 599, 711, 614]]<|/det|> D 3500 J <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 644, 918, 662]]<|/det|> 10 Which pair of changes, applied at the same time, always increases the pressure that a brick exerts on the ground? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 685, 535, 833]]<|/det|>
weight of brick
area of brick in
contact with ground
A
increase
increase
B
increase
decrease
C
decrease
increase
D
decrease
decrease

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
11 Two different pure substances, \(X\) and \(Y\), are heated. Both substance \(X\) and substance \(Y\) are initially in the solid state.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 750, 136]]<|/det|>
The graph shows how the temperature of each substance changes with time.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[292, 147, 708, 275]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 292, 537, 307]]<|/det|>
What does the graph tell us about the substances?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 318, 617, 335]]<|/det|>
A Substance \(X\) has a lower boiling point than substance \(Y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 343, 623, 361]]<|/det|>
B Substance \(X\) has a lower melting point than substance \(Y\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 369, 617, 386]]<|/det|>
C Substance \(Y\) has a lower boiling point than substance \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 394, 623, 412]]<|/det|>
D Substance \(Y\) has a lower melting point than substance \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 441, 435, 458]]<|/det|>
12 A liquid substance changes into a gas.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 470, 548, 487]]<|/det|>
Which property of the substance remains the same?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 497, 264, 516]]<|/det|>
A ability to flow

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 523, 277, 542]]<|/det|>
B compressibility

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 549, 209, 566]]<|/det|>
C shape

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 575, 217, 592]]<|/det|>
D volume

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 620, 523, 637]]<|/det|>
13 At room temperature, iron is difficult to compress.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 649, 629, 668]]<|/det|>
At the same temperature, oxygen is much easier to compress.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 679, 796, 698]]<|/det|>
Which comparison of the particles in iron and the particles in oxygen explains this?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 708, 465, 725]]<|/det|>
A The iron particles are closer together.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 734, 477, 751]]<|/det|>
B The iron particles have a greater mass.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 759, 465, 778]]<|/det|>
C The iron particles can be magnetised.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 785, 576, 803]]<|/det|>
D The iron particles have less average kinetic energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 645, 91]]<|/det|> 14 A teacher has a gas in a sealed syringe with a movable plunger. <|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 103, 714, 218]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 232, 918, 250]]<|/det|> The teacher slowly moves the plunger out of the syringe. The temperature of the gas remains constant. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 277, 741, 296]]<|/det|> Which row explains what happens to the pressure of the gas in the syringe? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 306, 854, 435]]<|/det|>
pressure of gas
explanation
A
decreases
gas particles collide with the syringe wall less frequently
B
decreases
gas particles collide with the syringe wall more frequently
C
increases
gas particles collide with the syringe wall less frequently
D
increases
gas particles collide with the syringe wall more frequently
<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 462, 570, 480]]<|/det|> 15 Evaporation occurs from the surface of a pool of water. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 493, 518, 508]]<|/det|> Which statement describes this change of state? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 521, 567, 538]]<|/det|> A Electrons move from the liquid and become a gas. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 548, 918, 565]]<|/det|> B Molecules that move from the liquid have the same energy as the molecules that stay in the liquid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 589, 554, 606]]<|/det|> C The more-energetic molecules escape the liquid. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 614, 570, 630]]<|/det|> D The more-energetic molecules remain in the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 74, 918, 91]]<|/det|>
16 Students test four rods of different materials, \(W, X, Y\) and \(Z\), to compare how well the materials conduct thermal energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 119, 463, 136]]<|/det|>
The rods are all the same size and shape.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 918, 165]]<|/det|>
The students use wax to stick a pin to one end of the first rod. The wax melts when it is warm. The other end of the rod is heated and the time taken for the pin to fall is recorded.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 193, 454, 210]]<|/det|>
The experiment is repeated for each rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 222, 623, 240]]<|/det|>
The students plot a chart of the time taken for each pin to fall.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 252, 711, 449]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 464, 350, 479]]<|/det|>
Which statement is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 492, 471, 508]]<|/det|>
A \(X\) is a better thermal conductor than Y .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 517, 474, 533]]<|/det|>
B \(Y\) is a better thermal conductor than W .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 542, 474, 559]]<|/det|>
C \(Z\) is a better thermal conductor than W .

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 567, 471, 587]]<|/det|>
D \(Z\) is a better thermal conductor than \(X\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 614, 918, 630]]<|/det|>
17 A student has four metal containers filled with the same volume of water at a temperature of \(80^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 659, 653, 675]]<|/det|>
The metal containers are put in a room at a temperature of \(20^{\circ} \mathrm{C}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 688, 808, 706]]<|/det|>
The metal containers are identical except for the texture and colour of their surfaces.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 718, 540, 735]]<|/det|>
Which surface will emit energy at the greatest rate?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 747, 234, 761]]<|/det|>
A dull black

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 772, 248, 788]]<|/det|>
B shiny black

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 798, 234, 813]]<|/det|>
C dull white

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 823, 248, 841]]<|/det|>
D shiny white

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 432, 91]]<|/det|> 18 A water wave has a speed of \(2.0 \mathrm{~m} / \mathrm{s}\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 103, 543, 120]]<|/det|> 4.0 complete waves pass a point every 10 seconds. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 135, 421, 150]]<|/det|> What is the wavelength of the wave? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 162, 211, 176]]<|/det|> A \(\quad 0.50 \mathrm{~m}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[284, 162, 377, 176]]<|/det|> B \(\quad 0.80 \mathrm{~m}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[450, 162, 535, 176]]<|/det|> C \(\quad 5.0 \mathrm{~m}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[616, 162, 700, 176]]<|/det|> D \(\quad 8.0 \mathrm{~m}\) <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[83, 208, 918, 223]]<|/det|> 19 Which row correctly describes the vibrations of a transverse wave and also gives a correct example of a transverse wave? <|ref|>table<|/ref|><|det|>[[113, 251, 667, 397]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 536, 576, 551]]<|/det|> 28 A mains-operated radio is a double-insulated appliance. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 564, 350, 579]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 591, 535, 607]]<|/det|> A The radio does not need a neutral connection. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 616, 380, 631]]<|/det|> B The radio must be earthed. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 642, 587, 657]]<|/det|> C The radio circuit is safe without a fuse or trip switch. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 669, 567, 684]]<|/det|> D The outer casing of the radio cannot become live. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 714, 489, 730]]<|/det|> 29 Which statement describes a magnetic field? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 742, 562, 758]]<|/det|> A It is a region where all objects experience a force. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 767, 631, 783]]<|/det|> B It is a region where all electric charges experience a force. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 792, 626, 809]]<|/det|> C It is a region where all magnetic poles experience a force. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 818, 559, 833]]<|/det|> D It is a region where all metals experience a force.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 605, 869, 621]]<|/det|> 32 A student investigates the turning effect on a current-carrying coil placed in a magnetic field. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 634, 766, 649]]<|/det|> The student changes the current in the coil and the number of turns on the coil. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 663, 634, 680]]<|/det|> Which two changes together must increase the turning effect? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 692, 637, 708]]<|/det|> A decreasing the current and decreasing the number of turns <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 718, 631, 734]]<|/det|> B decreasing the current and increasing the number of turns <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 743, 631, 760]]<|/det|> C increasing the current and decreasing the number of turns <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 769, 625, 785]]<|/det|> D increasing the current and increasing the number of turns

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[182, 441, 311, 459]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 466, 153, 481]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 490, 153, 506]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 515, 153, 531]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[133, 540, 153, 557]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 591, 867, 608]]<|/det|> 39 Electromagnetic radiation from distant galaxies is redshifted when observed from the Earth. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 620, 543, 637]]<|/det|> This is evidence that supports the Big Bang Theory. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 651, 350, 666]]<|/det|> Which statement is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 679, 703, 696]]<|/det|> A Light from galaxies that are moving towards the Earth is redshifted. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 704, 728, 721]]<|/det|> B Redshift is an increase in the wavelength of electromagnetic radiation. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 730, 843, 749]]<|/det|> C The Big Bang Theory says that the Solar System is expanding out into the Universe. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[117, 755, 921, 774]]<|/det|> D The Big Bang Theory says that, billions of years ago, the Universe expanded to its current size in a few seconds.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[80, 74, 521, 91]]<|/det|>
40 Which statement about the Milky Way is correct?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 101, 487, 118]]<|/det|>
A It is a galaxy made up of billions of stars.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 127, 518, 144]]<|/det|>
B It is a group of galaxies in our Solar System.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 154, 551, 170]]<|/det|>
C It is all the stars that we can see in the night sky.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 179, 648, 196]]<|/det|>
D It is the path taken by a comet when it gets close to the Sun.
